stringToolsRef.kebabCaseDesc: CSS classes, URL slugs, CLI flags
stringToolsRef.tipCaseConventions: Follow your language's conventions (PEP 8 for Python, Airbnb Style Guide for JS). snake_case is generally more readable; camelCase is more compact.
stringToolsRef.trimLinesUseCase: Clean copy-pasted data, remove trailing whitespace before commits
stringToolsRef.padLinesUseCase: Align columns in fixed-width formats, format tables
stringToolsRef.sortUseCase: Organize imports, hosts files, config entries, DNS records
stringToolsRef.sortNumericUseCase: Order version numbers, IP addresses, port lists, log counts
stringToolsRef.reverseLinesUseCase: Invert chronological logs, reverse stack traces
stringToolsRef.removeEmptyUseCase: Clean up multi-line configs, sanitize user lists
stringToolsRef.shuffleUseCase: Randomize test data, generate sample sets
stringToolsRef.tipNumericSort: Numeric sort extracts the leading number from each line, useful for lines like "192.168.1.1 - server1" or "v2.1.0 - release".
stringToolsRef.caseSensitiveBehavior: {{code1}} and {{code2}} are treated as different values
stringToolsRef.removeDuplicatesUseCase: Clean email lists, dedupe hostnames, sanitize IP lists
stringToolsRef.showDuplicatesUseCase: Find repeated entries in logs, identify conflicts
stringToolsRef.countOccurrencesUseCase: Analyze log frequency, find most common errors/IPs
stringToolsRef.tipCountOccurrences: Use "Count Occurrences" on server logs to quickly identify the most frequent IP addresses, error codes, or user agents.
stringToolsRef.securityNoteSql: Escaping single quotes helps but is not sufficient for SQL injection prevention. Always use parameterized queries/prepared statements in production code.
stringToolsRef.bestPracticeHtml: HTML entity encoding prevents basic XSS but is context-dependent. For full protection, encode on output (not input), use Content Security Policy (CSP), and leverage your framework's built-in protections.

infoBoxes.base64Info: Base64 encoding converts binary data to ASCII text. Commonly used for embedding images in HTML/CSS or transmitting data in URLs.
infoBoxes.hashInfo: Cryptographic hashes are one-way functions. The same input always produces the same output, but you cannot reverse the process.
infoBoxes.urlInfo: URL encoding replaces unsafe characters with percent-encoded values. Required for special characters in URLs and form data.
infoBoxes.hexInfo: Hexadecimal encoding represents each byte as two hex digits. Useful for debugging, displaying binary data, and configuration files.

loanPayoffMethods.title: Debt Payoff Methods
loanPayoffMethods.name: Loan Payoff Methods
loanPayoffMethods.subtitle: Snowball vs Avalanche: Which strategy is right for you?
loanPayoffMethods.description: Compare different loan payoff strategies and see potential savings.

navLinks.learnAboutLoans: Learn about loan types and predatory lending

comparison.introText: Both methods work by paying minimums on all debts while putting extra money toward one "target" debt. The difference is how you choose which debt to target first.
comparison.tableLabel: Comparison of Snowball and Avalanche methods
comparison.avalancheStrategy: Pay off highest interest rate first
comparison.snowballMotivation: Quick wins early - debts disappear fast
comparison.avalancheMotivation: Maximum savings - math is on your side
comparison.snowballBestFor: People who need motivation, have given up before, or have many small debts
comparison.avalancheBestFor: Analytical people, those with high-interest debt, or anyone who can stay motivated without quick wins
comparison.researchText: Studies from the Kellogg School of Management found that people using the snowball method are more likely to eliminate debt completely - small wins create momentum. However, avalanche saves about 1.3% more interest on average. The best method is the one you'll stick with.

psychology.introText: Research shows that personal finance is 80% behavior and only 20% head knowledge. Here's what behavioral economics tells us:
psychology.proportionalProgressText: When you make a $150 payment on a $600 balance, you've wiped out 25%. On a $6,000 balance, it barely registers. Our brains respond more to proportion than absolute amount.
psychology.debtAccountAversionText: We keep mental "accounts" for each debt. Closing an entire account feels like a complete win, even if it's small. This explains why eliminating one small debt can be more motivating than making equal progress on a large one.
psychology.keyInsightText: The best debt payoff method is the one you'll actually stick with until completion. If the avalanche method causes you to give up after 6 months, the snowball method that you complete is better for you.

faq.includeMortgageAnswer: Usually no. Focus on consumer debt first (credit cards, auto loans, personal loans). Mortgages are long-term, often have tax benefits, and the interest rate is typically lower than other debts.
faq.zeroPercentRatesAnswer: Be careful! Enter the post-promotional APR that will apply when the 0% period ends. If you can't pay it off before then, plan for the higher rate.
faq.onlyMinimums: What if I can only pay minimums?
faq.onlyMinimumsAnswer: Both methods produce the same result when you can only pay minimums. Focus on finding extra money through budgeting, side income, or reducing expenses. Even $50 extra per month makes a significant difference.
faq.switchMethodsAnswer: Absolutely! Some people start with snowball to get momentum, then switch to avalanche once they've built the habit. The important thing is to keep going.

loanPayoffMethods.footer: Debt Payoff Methods Guide - Works offline, no data stored, no sign-up required

loanReference.title: Loan Reference
loanReference.name: Loan Reference
loanReference.subtitle: Understand loan types, spot warning signs, and make informed decisions
loanReference.description: Reference guide for loan types, terms, and calculations.

sections.predatoryLending: Predatory Lending: Warning Signs to Watch For
sections.loanCalculator: See the Real Cost: Loan Calculator
sections.redFlagChecker: Interactive: Is This Loan Safe? (Red Flag Checker)

loanReference.loanTypesIntro: Not all loans are created equal. Here's a breakdown of common loan types and what to expect:
loanReference.predatoryIntro: Predatory lenders target people who are desperate, inexperienced, or don't know better. They're counting on you not understanding what you're signing. Here's how to spot them:
loanReference.calculatorIntro: Enter a loan amount to see how much you'd actually pay back with different APRs. The difference is eye-opening.

analogies.speedLimit: Think of APR like a speed limit:
analogies.speedLimitDesc: Under 10% is cruising in a school zone (safe). 10-36% is highway speed (manageable). Over 36%? You're in a race car with no brakes - that's when things get dangerous.
analogies.videoGameTitle: Think of it like a video game:
analogies.videoGame: Predatory lenders are like those "free-to-play" games that seem free but are designed to drain your wallet. The terms look simple until you're stuck paying $500 to unlock the next level (or in this case, to avoid destroying your credit).

redFlags.title: Major Red Flags
redFlags.highInterestDesc: Anything over 36% APR is a warning sign. Over 100%? That's loan shark territory.
redFlags.noCreditCheckDesc: Sounds good, but it means they're not checking if you can afford to pay it back. They don't care.
redFlags.pressureSignDesc: "This offer expires today!" or "Don't you need this money?" are manipulation tactics.
redFlags.hiddenFeesDesc: Origination fees, processing fees, early payoff penalties. If they're hard to find, that's on purpose.
redFlags.balloonDesc: Small payments for months, then suddenly you owe thousands. It's a trap.

safeSigns.licensed: Licensed and regulated - Check for NMLS registration number
safeSigns.clearDisclosure: Clear disclosure - All terms, fees, and APR shown upfront BEFORE you sign
safeSigns.noPressure: No pressure - Gives you time to read, think, and compare
safeSigns.rightToCancel: Right to cancel - 3 days to back out (federal law)
safeSigns.affordablePayments: Reasonable repayment - Payments you can actually afford

calculator.title: Compare Good Loan vs Predatory Loan
calculator.savings: By choosing the good loan, you save:

checker.intro: Thinking about taking out a loan? Check off any red flags that apply to see if you should proceed:
checker.flag1Desc: Consumer protection groups consider 36%+ APR to be predatory
checker.flag2Desc: Legitimate lenders check credit to ensure you can repay
checker.flag3: They're pressuring me to sign today
checker.flag3Desc: Good lenders give you time to think and compare options
checker.flag4: The fees are hard to find or unclear
checker.flag4Desc: Hidden fees are a major warning sign
checker.flag5: There's a large "balloon payment" at the end
checker.flag5Desc: Small payments followed by a huge lump sum is a trap
checker.flag6: I can't easily find their license/registration info
checker.flag6Desc: Legitimate lenders display their NMLS number
checker.flag7: They want access to my bank account to auto-withdraw
checker.flag7Desc: This gives them control over your money
checker.flag8: My monthly payment would be more than 10% of my income
checker.flag8Desc: Unaffordable payments lead to debt traps
checker.resultSafeDesc: No major red flags detected. This loan might be reasonable - but still compare rates from at least 3 lenders before deciding.
checker.resultCautionDesc: You've identified 1-2 warning signs. This doesn't automatically mean it's a bad loan, but you should investigate further and consider alternatives.
checker.resultDangerDesc: Multiple red flags detected. This loan has significant warning signs of predatory lending. Strongly consider walking away and exploring other options like credit unions, family loans, or saving up instead.

quiz.question: Question
quiz.intro: Test your knowledge with these real-world scenarios. See if you can spot the best financial decision.
quiz.scenario1Text: Your car breaks down and needs a $800 repair. You need your car to get to work. A payday lender offers you $800 today with "just $100 in fees" due in 2 weeks. Your credit union offers an emergency loan at 18% APR with $50/month payments over 18 months.
quiz.scenario1OptionA: Take the payday loan - $100 fee sounds reasonable and I get the money today
quiz.scenario1OptionB: Take the credit union loan - lower total cost even though it takes longer
quiz.scenario1OptionC: Take both - use payday for now, credit union to pay it off
quiz.scenario1CorrectText: The credit union loan costs about $932 total ($800 + $132 interest). The payday loan's "$100 fee" is actually 650% APR! If you can't pay in 2 weeks, fees compound and you could owe $1,500+ in months. Always calculate the true APR.
quiz.scenario1IncorrectText: That $100 "fee" on an $800 loan for 2 weeks equals 650% APR! The credit union loan at 18% costs about $932 total over 18 months. The payday loan could cost $1,500+ if you need to "roll it over." Always calculate the true APR, not just the upfront fee.
quiz.scenario2Text: You're 19 and want to build credit. A store offers you their credit card with 29.99% APR and a $500 limit. A secured credit card from a bank requires a $200 deposit but has 18% APR. Your parent offers to add you as an authorized user on their card.
quiz.scenario2OptionA: Store card - higher limit and I can get rewards at that store
quiz.scenario2OptionB: Secured card - lower APR and it's from a real bank
quiz.scenario2OptionC: Authorized user first, then secured card - builds credit with less risk
quiz.scenario2CorrectText: Being an authorized user lets you build credit history with zero risk - you don't even need to use the card. Then you can get your own secured card to establish independent credit. Store cards often have predatory rates and should be avoided when starting out.
quiz.scenario2IncorrectText: Store cards have some of the highest APRs (29.99%!) and tempt you to overspend at one store. The smartest path is: become an authorized user first (free credit building), then get a secured card. This builds credit with minimal risk of debt.
quiz.scenario3Text: You owe $3,000 on a credit card at 24% APR. You receive a balance transfer offer: 0% APR for 12 months, then 26% APR. There's a 3% transfer fee ($90). You can afford to pay $275/month.
quiz.scenario3OptionA: Don't transfer - the fee and higher eventual APR aren't worth it
quiz.scenario3OptionB: Transfer it - pay $275/month and finish in 11 months at 0%
quiz.scenario3OptionC: Transfer and pay minimums - save the extra money
quiz.scenario3CorrectText: At $275/month for 11 months = $3,025 total (including the $90 fee). Without the transfer, at 24% APR paying $275/month, you'd pay about $360 in interest. The transfer saves you ~$270! The key is paying it off BEFORE the 0% period ends.
quiz.scenario3IncorrectText: Transfer + pay $275/month = $3,025 total (11 months). Without transfer at 24% APR = ~$3,360 total. That's $270 saved! BUT if you only pay minimums, you won't finish before 0% ends, and 26% APR kicks in on the remaining balance. The transfer only works if you commit to paying it off fast.
quiz.scenario4Text: A "debt consolidation company" contacts you offering to combine all your debts into one "easy payment." They want you to stop paying creditors directly and pay them instead. They promise to negotiate lower balances.
quiz.scenario4OptionA: Decline - this sounds like a debt settlement scam that could hurt my credit
quiz.scenario4OptionB: Sign up - one payment sounds easier to manage
quiz.scenario4OptionC: Try it for a few months - I can always quit if it doesn't work
quiz.scenario4CorrectText: Legitimate debt consolidation is a loan that pays off your other debts. "Debt settlement" companies that want you to stop paying creditors are often scams - they pocket your money while your credit tanks and creditors sue you. If you need help, try a non-profit credit counseling agency instead.
quiz.scenario4IncorrectText: This is a debt settlement scam, not consolidation. They'll take your money, tell creditors to wait, and your credit score will plummet. Many of these companies fold before helping you, leaving you worse off. Real help comes from non-profit credit counseling agencies or legitimate consolidation loans from banks/credit unions.
quiz.scorePerfect: Perfect score! You have excellent financial instincts. Keep that skeptical eye on loan offers!
quiz.scoreGreat: Great job! You know how to spot most financial traps. Review the explanations for the ones you missed.
quiz.scoreOk: Not bad! You caught some red flags but missed a few. Review the scenarios above to strengthen your knowledge.
quiz.scoreNeedsWork: You might be vulnerable to predatory lending. Please review all the explanations above - this knowledge could save you thousands!

callouts.apr36Warning: Any loan with APR over 36% is considered predatory by consumer protection groups. If you see triple-digit APR, run.
callouts.legitimateLendersWant: Legitimate lenders WANT you to understand the terms because they want you to pay them back. Predatory lenders profit when you CAN'T pay - that's when fees pile up.

a11y.noRedFlags: No red flags detected. This loan may be reasonable.

results.title: MTU Calculation Results
results.clientDeviceMtuNote: Use this value for devices behind the VPN gateway when Path MTU Discovery (PMTUD) is blocked or unreliable. This prevents packet fragmentation and black-holing.

pmtud.title: Path MTU Discovery Commands
pmtud.testCommandsHelp: Run these commands to test if packets of this size can reach the target without fragmentation. If you receive "Packet needs to be fragmented" or similar errors, reduce the MTU and try again.
pmtud.howToFind: How to Find Your Path MTU
pmtud.step2: Run the command for your OS
pmtud.step3: If packets get through, your path MTU is at least this size
pmtud.step4: If you get fragmentation errors, reduce MTU by 10-20 bytes and retry
pmtud.step5: The largest size that works is your path MTU

warnings.negativePayload: Negative payload! MTU is too small for selected protocols.
warnings.tunnelMtuBelow1280: Tunnel MTU is below 1280 bytes. Consider adjusting your base MTU or tunnel settings.
warnings.effectiveMtuBelowIpv4Min: Effective MTU is below IPv4 minimum (576 bytes). Fragmentation may occur.
warnings.effectiveMtuBelowIpv6Min: Effective MTU is below IPv6 minimum (1280 bytes). Connection issues may occur.
warnings.negativePayloadStack: Negative payload! Remove some layers or increase MTU.
warnings.verySmallPayload: Very small payload ({{bytes}} bytes). Consider optimizing your stack.

validation.mtuMinimum: MTU must be at least 68 bytes (IPv4 minimum)
validation.mtuMaximum: MTU cannot exceed 9000 bytes (Jumbo frame maximum)

accessibility.resultsAnnounce: MTU calculation complete. Effective MTU is {{effectiveMtu}} bytes with {{payload}} bytes available payload.
accessibility.stackResultsAnnounce: Protocol stack built with {{layers}} layers. Total overhead is {{overhead}} bytes with {{payload}} bytes payload.
accessibility.pmtudResultsAnnounce: Path MTU Discovery commands generated for {{host}}. ICMP payload size is {{payloadSize}} bytes.
accessibility.buildProtocolStackButton: Build protocol stack and calculate payload
accessibility.generatePmtudButton: Generate Path MTU Discovery test commands

reference.title: MTU Reference
reference.commonVpnValue: Common safe value for VPN tunnels
reference.mtuDefinition: MTU (Maximum Transmission Unit) is the maximum packet size including all headers at Layer 3 and above.
reference.mssDefinition: MSS (Maximum Segment Size) is the maximum TCP payload only, calculated as: MTU - IP header - TCP header.
reference.mssExample: Example: With 1500 MTU and IPv4/TCP: MSS = 1500 - 20 (IPv4) - 20 (TCP) = 1460 bytes
reference.ipsecTunnelComponents: Outer IP (20) + ESP header (8) + IV (16) + trailer (2) + padding (~15) + ICV (12)
reference.ipsecTransportComponents: ESP header (8) + IV (16) + trailer (2) + padding (~15) + ICV (12)
reference.wireguardComponents: UDP header (8) + WG header (16) + Poly1305 auth (16)
